results.title: Japan's art from the land
results.creator_credit: Hugh Gage, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: The famous artist Shuson Kono, paints a mountain landscape capturing the serenity of nature in the still muted-toned ponds that border the Katsura, the 17th century Imperial Palace. Bamboo flutes and vocal chorus intensify the deeply reflective mood of this poetic film. Also includes images of rural Japan and illustrates the designing of various Japanese gardens.

results.title: January 26 - A.B Original (2016)
results.brief_description: January 26 was the hit single for hip hop duo A.B Original, which is made up of Briggs and Trials. In their debut album Reclaim Australia they frequently address issues facing Indigenous Australians.

constellations_other.name: Outlaws and the end
constellations_other.description: Tracing connections from Sweet Country to Australian westerns and resistance to white colonial narratives.

results.title: James Galway Program 8
results.brief_description: James Galway introduces a small orchestra performance of Saint Saens “Carnival of the Animals” to which William Rushton reads verses by Jeremy Nicholas. Orchestra: Andrew Ball, Julian Jacobson, Piano; Paul Barrit, Leader; Mayum Seilor, Violin; Tim Boulton, Viola; Timothy Hugh, Cello; Chi-Chi Nwanoku, Bass; Philippa Davies, Flute; E Johnson, Clarinet; Evelyn Glennie; Percussion. Rated: G

results.title: James Galway Program 6
results.brief_description: James Galway introduces the Kings Singers to sing “O Lusty May” (Scots 16C) “Woe worth the time” (Scots 16C), “There’s Nae Luck” (trad), “O Waly” (trad - cello accompaniment Timothy Hughs), “Sea Runes” by M Davies, “The Bee by Bridge”, “The Flight of the Bumble Bee” by Rimsky Korsakov, “Creole Love Call” by Duke Ellington. Rated G

results.title: James Galway Program 3
results.brief_description: Famous flautist, James Galway, introduces Nigel Kennedy, the violin virtuoso, with Peter Pettinger on piano to perform “Notta” by Manuel de Falla, 1st movement of a sonata by Ravel, Gershwin’s “2nd Prelude”, Gershwin’s “1st Prelude” and finally “Alls Blues” by Miles Davis. Rated: G

results.title: James Galway Program 2
results.brief_description: In this program James Galway, famous flautist introduces John Lill, the pianist to perform as soloist “The Chaconne” by Bach, “Nocturne in E Minor, Opus 72” by Chopin and the “Finale of the 7th Sonata” by Prokofiev. Rated: G

results.title: James Galway Program 1
results.brief_description: James Galway, famous flautist, is accompanied by pianist Philip Moll, to perform “Sonata 1st Movement” by Poulenc, a “Fantasie” by Faure, “Schon Rosmarin” by Kriesler, “Carmen Fantasy” arranged by Borne based on the work of Bizet. Rated: G

results.title: Jamboree
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Owen Brothers Animated Films
results.brief_description: The story begins with preparations near Melbourne for the Pacific Jamboree, which 10,500 scouts, from Pacific as well as European countries, attended. The film also includes performances of different national dances.

results.title: Jaipur
results.creator_credit: Shanti Varma, Ezra Mir and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The ancient rose-red city of Jaipur and the surrounding country of Rajput. Designed on a grand scale by Jai Singh in 1728, the walled city contains many remarkable temples, gardens and palaces. Nearby is the old palace, with man]gnificent frescoes, inlay work and decorated ceilings. The fort recalls the history of Rajput and its defence against waves of invaders. The observatory built by Jai Singh; collections of manuscripts and paintings; Palace of Winds; craftsmen at work.
